The laboratory studies show an increased bleeding time and normal PT and PTT, which rules out factor deficiencies. The enlarged platelets and inability to aggregate to ristocetin suggest Bernard-Soulier syndrome, a rare inherited platelet disorder. Aspirin or NSAID use is unlikely to cause heavy vaginal bleeding for 4 months. Glanzmann thrombasthenia is another rare inherited platelet disorder, but it is characterized by normal platelet size and quantity. von Willebrand disease is a common bleeding disorder but it is characterized by normal platelet count and morphology.

The girl has a low platelet count, prolonged bleeding time, and platelets that do not aggregate to ristocetin, which suggests platelet dysfunction. Among the given options, only Bernard-Soulier syndrome is a disorder of platelet dysfunction characterized by enlarged platelets and absent or reduced platelet aggregation to ristocetin. This syndrome is inherited in an autosomal recessive manner and is caused by a deficiency or abnormality in the glycoprotein complex GPIb/IX/V on the platelet membrane. This deficiency leads to impaired binding of platelets to von Willebrand factor and subsequently impaired platelet adhesion and function. The family history of easy bruising in the brother and bleeding during childbirth in the mother supports the genetic nature of the disorder.
